intro: Physalis campanulata, commonly known as the common groundcherry, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to the eastern United States. It produces small, yellow-orange fruits enclosed in a papery, lantern-like calyx. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and thrives in full sun to partial shade. Its leaves are heart-shaped and have a slightly hairy texture, while its flowers are bell-shaped and usually pink or white. The fruit is edible when fully ripe, often used in jams and desserts.
